intro: Vachellia gummifera, commonly known as the gum arabic tree, is a flowering plant native to Africa and the Arabian Peninsula. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its thorny stems and small, yellowish-green flowers. The tree produces a sticky, resinous gum that is harvested for commercial use as a natural gum arabic. Its leaves are trifoliate, and the plant is often found in arid or semi-arid environments. Vachellia gummifera plays an important ecological role in stabilizing soils and providing forage for livestock.
